items.title: inventory-app
The http2 server throws TypeError `server.shouldUpgradeCallback` is not a function
items.body: ### Version origin/main branch ### Platform ```text windows "$([Environment]::OSVersion.VersionString) $(('x86', 'x64')[[Environment]::Is64BitOperatingSystem])" ``` ### Subsystem http ### What steps will reproduce the bug? ```js import { createSecureServer } from 'http2' let server = createSecureServer(...) server.on('upgrade', () => { ... }) server.listen(443) // Create a websocket connection to port 443 ``` ### How often does it reproduce? Is there a required condition? Must appear ### What is the expected behavior? Why is that the expected behavior? Websocket connection is normal ### What do you see instead? ### Additional information relates to: https://github.com/nodejs/node/pull/59824 Can you (@pimterry) add relevant test cases for this PR? http server, http2 server and test websocket connection

items.title: ERR_INTERNAL_ASSERTION
items.body:
### Version

v20.10.0

### Platform

```text
Linux MigrationServer 5.15.0-144-generic #157-Ubuntu SMP Mon Jun 16 07:33:10 UTC 2025 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux
```

### Subsystem

_No response_

### What steps will reproduce the bug?

Performing the long-running script that includes a ton of external API calls and a few DB operations with MySQL.

### How often does it reproduce? Is there a required condition?

It threw the same error six times, and then it suddenly went away.

### What is the expected behavior? Why is that the expected behavior?

Stack trace error mentioned below

### What do you see instead?

Stack trace error mentioned below

### Additional information

Error [ERR_INTERNAL_ASSERTION]: This is caused by either a bug in Node.js or incorrect usage of Node.js internals.
Please open an issue with this stack trace at https://github.com/nodejs/node/issues

    at assert (node:internal/assert:14:11)
    at internalConnectMultiple (node:net:1118:3)
    at Timeout.internalConnectMultipleTimeout (node:net:1687:3)
    at listOnTimeout (node:internal/timers:575:11)
    at process.processTimers (node:internal/timers:514:7)

items.title: Edusecure
Ability to block installs of packages that were published less than x days ago

labels.name: feature request
labels.description: Issues that request new features to be added to Node.js.

items.body:
### What is the problem this feature will solve?

This could be a great help against installing hijacked packages that published malicious updates (as happening a LOT recently), which are often removed from npm fairly quickly.
This feature could be used to make sure that npm and/or the maintainers have enough time to remove malicious updates before the version is allowed to be installed.
It might also help with #59911.

### What is the feature you are proposing to solve the problem?

I'd love to have a way to tell Node.js (e.g. in an .npmrc file) to not allow installing any packages that aren't older than x days/hours/minutes.
This could be seen as an automation of always running `npm install --before (Today-xDays)`, which I assume already contains the necessary logic for this.

A configurable list of exceptions to this rule or at least a workaround command flag would be very appreciated, of course.

### What alternatives have you considered?

pnpm has recently implemented a similar functionality in their [v10.16](https://github.com/pnpm/pnpm/releases/tag/v10.16.0).

In theory, npm install [--before](https://docs.npmjs.com/cli/v11/using-npm/config#before) allows to construct this behavior, but adding that to every npm i and npm ci is not really a feasible solution.

This functionality can also be (partly) achieved through the dependency management itself (e.g. GitHub's Dependabot). However, implementing it in Node.js itself helps in keeping the devices themselves safe and making sure that developers don't accidentally install malicious packages or even push them into repositories.

items.title: Node 24.8.0 has a regression in VM

labels.name: vm
labels.description: Issues and PRs related to the vm subsystem.

items.body:
### Version

24.8.0

### Platform

```text
Linux laptop 6.14.0-29-generic #29~24.04.1-Ubuntu SMP PREEMPT_DYNAMIC Thu Aug 14 16:52:50 UTC 2 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux

But not related to the problem, any platform
```

### Subsystem

_No response_

### What steps will reproduce the bug?

Investigating, works fine with 24.7.0

Now:

```
Module status must be unlinked
```

Ref - https://github.com/webpack/webpack/pull/19901

### How often does it reproduce? Is there a required condition?

Always

### What is the expected behavior? Why is that the expected behavior?

Works without any errors

### What do you see instead?

Error with `Module status must be unlinked`

### Additional information

I think https://github.com/nodejs/node/pull/59000 create a regression

import { test } from "node:test"

node --test

  Error: test error msg

```

```
  {}
```

items.title: fetch requests crashes node process when trying to see more details in chrome dev tools with new --experimental-network-inspection flag

labels.name: inspector
labels.description: Issues and PRs related to the V8 inspector protocol

items.body:
### Version

v22.18.0

### Platform

```text
Darwin obil-obar-zik.local 24.6.0 Darwin Kernel Version 24.6.0: Mon Jul 14 11:28:30 PDT 2025; root:xnu-11417.140.69~1/RELEASE_ARM64_T6030 arm64
```

### Subsystem

_No response_

### What steps will reproduce the bug?

1. Create a file with this content:
```js
await fetch('https://www.google.com')
```

2. Run the command
```bash
node  --inspect-wait --experimental-network-inspection script.js
```

3. Open Chrome Dev Tools and select the request to view more details

### How often does it reproduce? Is there a required condition?

Every Time you click the request in the browser, the node process crashes

### What is the expected behavior? Why is that the expected behavior?

To show the request details and not crash the node

items.title: deb.nodesource.com is buggy

labels.name: wrong repo
labels.description: Issues that should be opened in another repository.

items.body:
### Version

24.x

### Platform

```text
Distributor ID:	Ubuntu
Description:	Ubuntu 24.04.2 LTS
Release:	24.04
Codename:	noble
```

### Subsystem

_No response_

### What steps will reproduce the bug?

apt-get update

### How often does it reproduce? Is there a required condition?

Always, since 2+ weeks.

### What is the expected behavior? Why is that the expected behavior?

No errors on apt-get update, because this is how it should work.

### What do you see instead?

```
...
Get:21 http://de.archive.ubuntu.com/ubuntu noble/universe amd64 Packages [15.0 MB]
Get:22 https://deb.nodesource.com/node_24.x nodistro/main amd64 Packages [3,026 B]
Err:22 https://deb.nodesource.com/node_24.x nodistro/main amd64 Packages

### Additional information

Script automatically installing nodejs fail because of bad repo contents. It should be fixed immediately.

Welcome to CodeTriad

We are a technical group focused on creating innovative solutions in software development, web technologies, and AI-driven applications. Our mission is to combine skills and teamwork to deliver high-quality projects.

About Us

CodeTriad Group is formed by passionate developers and technologists who believe in learning, sharing, and building impactful projects. We thrive on collaboration and innovation.

Our Services

  • Web Development (HTML, CSS, JavaScript, React)
  • Mobile App Development
  • AI & Machine Learning Projects
  • Cloud & Deployment Solutions

items.title: Edusecure-demo
Reached heap limit Allocation failed in Node services
items.body: ### Version 22 ### Platform ```text Linux core-849464d845-jwj7t 5.15.0-1088-azure #97-Ubuntu SMP Tue Apr 22 18:58:00 UTC 2025 x86_64 Linux ``` ### Subsystem Azure Kubernetes Services v1.32.3 ### What steps will reproduce the bug? Today we started to identify the error `FATAL ERROR: Reached heap limit Allocation failed - JavaScript heap out of memory` in some microservices built on Node. The base image of these microservices uses the image `gcr.io/distroless/nodejs22-debian12:nonroot` as a base, as shown in the example below. ```dockerfile FROM node:22-bookworm-slim AS dependencies # setup dependencies cmake and g++ are necessary for rfc-sdk RUN apt-get update && \ apt-get install -y openssl --no-install-recommends # Download additional libs to copy to distroless image. rfc-sdk depends on libuuid1 RUN cd /tmp && \ apt-get download \ openssl && \ mkdir -p /dpkg/var/lib/dpkg/status.d/ && \ for deb in *.deb; do \ package_name=$(dpkg-deb -I ${deb} | awk '/^ Package: .*$/ {print $2}'); \ echo "Process: ${package_name}"; \ dpkg --ctrl-tarfile $deb | tar -Oxvf - ./control > /dpkg/var/lib/dpkg/status.d/${package_name}; \ dpkg --extract $deb /dpkg || exit 10; \ done COPY ./prisma ./package.json ./package-lock.json ./.npmrc /app/ WORKDIR /app RUN npm ci --omit=dev && npx prisma generate FROM gcr.io/distroless/nodejs22-debian12:nonroot # Instruct prisma to not download checksum files for engine # Required to run in registry_only mode ENV PRISMA_ENGINES_CHECKSUM_IGNORE_MISSING=1 # Copy additional libs to distroless image COPY --from=dependencies --chown=root:root /dpkg / # Copy application files COPY --chown=nonroot:nonroot ./dist /home/nonroot/dist COPY --chown=nonroot:nonroot ./prisma ./package.json ./package-lock.json /home/nonroot/ COPY --chown=nonroot:nonroot --from=dependencies /app/node_modules /home/nonroot/node_modules USER nonroot WORKDIR /home/nonroot EXPOSE 3000 HEALTHCHECK NONE CMD ["-r", "./dist/opentelemetry.js", "dist/main"] ``` The error began today after a release of a microservice in production, which did not have significant changes in code or library versions used, only some error handling. We suspect that it may be something related to the base image of Node (gcr.io/distroless/nodejs22-debian12) that is updated every time a CI/CD pipeline is executed. Similarly, I noticed that today the tags of the images on gcr.io were updated in practically all images involving Node, see evidence below. https://console.cloud.google.com/artifacts/docker/distroless/us/gcr.io/nodejs22-debian12 ### How often does it reproduce? Is there a required condition? The error occurs always in microservices that use the base image `gcr.io/distroless/nodejs22-debian12:nonroot` or `node:22-alpine`. We noticed that when modifying the Docker image to use the base `node:20-alpine` the error does not happen. ### What is the expected behavior? Why is that the expected behavior? The expected behavior is that the microservice runs without `FATAL ERROR: Reached heap limit Allocation failed - JavaScript heap out of memory` errors. ### What do you see instead? ``` 2025-09-08 14:58:51.064 1: 0xe1803a node::OOMErrorHandler(char const*, v8::OOMDetails const&) [/nodejs/bin/node] 2025-09-08 14:58:51.064 [1:0x1a876000] 60788 ms: Mark-Compact (reduce) 250.1 (257.8) -> 249.7 (257.3) MB, pooled: 0 MB, 1102.87 / 0.00 ms (average mu = 0.049, current mu = 0.000) last resort; GC in old space requested 2025-09-08 14:58:51.064 2025-09-08 14:58:51.064 2025-09-08 14:58:51.064 FATAL ERROR: Ineffective mark-compacts near heap limit Allocation failed - JavaScript heap out of memory 2025-09-08 14:58:51.064 <--- Last few GCs ---> 2025-09-08 14:58:51.064 2025-09-08 14:58:51.064 ----- Native stack trace ----- 2025-09-08 14:58:51.064 <--- JS stacktrace ---> 2025-09-08 14:58:51.064 2025-09-08 14:58:51.064 2025-09-08 14:58:51.064 [1:0x1a876000] 69893 ms: Mark-Compact (reduce) 250.5 (257.8) -> 250.0 (257.8) MB, pooled: 0 MB, 210.63 / 0.00 ms (+ 789.2 ms in 0 steps since start of marking, biggest step 0.0 ms, walltime since start of marking 1003 ms) (average mu = 0.799, current 2025-09-08 14:58:51.065 2: 0x11ec9c0 v8::Utils::ReportOOMFailure(v8::internal::Isolate*, char const*, v8::OOMDetails const&) [/nodejs/bin/node] 2025-09-08 14:58:51.065 3: 0x11ecc97 v8::internal::V8::FatalProcessOutOfMemory(v8::internal::Isolate*, char const*, v8::OOMDetails const&) [/nodejs/bin/node] 2025-09-08 14:58:51.066 5: 0x141a5a3 [/nodejs/bin/node] 2025-09-08 14:58:51.066 4: 0x141a575 [/nodejs/bin/node] 2025-09-08 14:58:51.067 6: 0x143367a [/nodejs/bin/node] 2025-09-08 14:58:51.067 7: 0x1436848 [/nodejs/bin/node] 2025-09-08 14:58:51.068 8: 0x1c9c351 [/nodejs/bin/node] ``` ### Additional information _No response_

items.title: What's the state of vm.Module? Can I help push it forward?

labels.name: vm
labels.description: Issues and PRs related to the vm subsystem.

labels.name: experimental
labels.description: Issues and PRs related to experimental features.

items.body:
I want to build a plugin system using `node:vm` (plugins are able to interact with the OS like any other nodejs script, so for my use case isolation is not required as code already must be trusted). Plugins are able to be a single file, or an actual npm module with its own package.json. In order to provide plugin context in globals (i.e. the global variable `pluginAPI` will be a different object in different plugins) I would like to use `node:vm`.

The complication arises when a plugin has `"type": "module"` in its package.json. I have two options to support this:
1. Use `vm.Module` which is currently "1 - Experimental" in the stability index, and has been since it was introduced in node 13
2. Manually parse `import` statements and re-implement all the functionality, which might introduce a cat-and-mouse game of getting all the subtleties

What's my better bet here? Are the maintainers still interested in adding ESM support to this? If so maybe I should help push it forward instead of implementing my own ESM using ducktape and zipties.

items.title: Add `CookieStore`

labels.name: feature request
labels.description: Issues that request new features to be added to Node.js.

items.body:
### What is the problem this feature will solve?

Storing cookies between HTTP requests.

### What is the feature you are proposing to solve the problem?

Re-implementing the [`CookieStore`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CookieStore) class as a pure (doesn't actually store cookies globally) Node.js global/exported class. (it is worth noting that `new CookieStore()` doesn't work in browsers, so this will be Node-exclusive)
Then, userland request libraries can accept a `CookieStore` instance as an option.

### What alternatives have you considered?

1. Polyfilling the `CookieStore` instance.
2. [`got`](https://github.com/sindresorhus/got) (userland request library) presently provides server-side cookie support by relying on the functionally-similar [`tough-cookie`](https://github.com/salesforce/tough-cookie). `tough-cookie` exposes a `CookieJar` class that manages cookies, and an instance is passed straight to `got`.

items.title: repl: variables becoming undefined
items.body:
### Version

24.x

### Platform

```text
All
```

### Subsystem

repl

### What steps will reproduce the bug?

```
jasnell@FF4V42X6YN ~ % nvm use 22
Now using node v22.19.0 (npm v10.9.3)
jasnell@FF4V42X6YN ~ % node
Welcome to Node.js v22.19.0.
Type ".help" for more information.
> m = {}
{}
> delete m.n
true
> m
{}
> .exit
jasnell@FF4V42X6YN ~ % nvm use 24
Now using node v24.7.0 (npm v11.5.1)
jasnell@FF4V42X6YN ~ % node
Welcome to Node.js v24.7.0.
Type ".help" for more information.
> m = {}
{}
> delete m.n
Uncaught ReferenceError: m is not defined
> m
Uncaught ReferenceError: m is not defined
>
```

### How often does it reproduce? Is there a required condition?

Always

### What is the expected behavior? Why is that the expected behavior?

m should not be `ReferenceError`

### What do you see instead?

See the repro

### Additional information

_No response_

items.title: Distinguish test abort from all tests passed

labels.name: tools
labels.description: Issues and PRs related to the tools directory.

items.body:
### Version

_No response_

### Platform

```text
mac m1
```

### Subsystem

tools

### What steps will reproduce the bug?

run tools/test.py

abort test before any failure detected

### How often does it reproduce? Is there a required condition?

always

### What is the expected behavior? Why is that the expected behavior?

test aborted

### What do you see instead?

all tests passed

### Additional information

During run tools/test.py "All tests passed." is printed even when the user aborted the test using the keyboard (e.g., Ctrl+C), as long as no test failures had occurred.

This can be confusing. I hope that different output would be printed.

items.title: Frontend Error : There's non toggle button at every piece of code in file system doc.

labels.name: doc
labels.description: Issues and PRs related to the documentations.

items.body: ### Affected URL(s) https://nodejs.org/docs/latest/api/fs.html ### Description of the problem There's non toggle button at every piece of code in file system doc. This would be of no use if the developer has not imported the fs module in every piece of code just like in any other docs. These are two refernces of the problem.

items.title: REPL performs unwanted autocompletion on pressing Enter

labels.name: repl
labels.description: Issues and PRs related to the REPL subsystem.

items.body:
### Version

v24.7.0

### Platform

```text
Linux (hostname) 6.14.11-300.fc42.x86_64 #1 SMP PREEMPT_DYNAMIC Tue Jun 10 16:24:16 UTC 2025 x86_64 GNU/Linux
```

### Subsystem

_No response_

### What steps will reproduce the bug?

1. Start an interactive REPL session
2. Enter `typeof Reflect.construct`

### How often does it reproduce? Is there a required condition?

Reliably reproducible.

### What is the expected behavior? Why is that the expected behavior?

The result of `typeof Reflect.construct` is printed (`'function'`) and the text `typeof Reflect.construct` is saved in the REPL history.


### What do you see instead?

You literally cannot enter the text `typeof Reflect.construct`!

Instead, the line is autocompleted to `typeof Reflect.constructor` when you press Enter. The result of `typeof Reflect.constructor` is printed (which is also `'function'`; 🤷). The text `typeof Reflect.constructor` is saved in the REPL history.

### Additional information

You can work around this by typing a space character after `construct`. But the behaviour of autocomplete plus commit on Enter is potentially destructive; I'd expect Tab to do autocompletion without committing.

items.title: ERR_INTERNAL_ASSERTION in 22.18 and 22.19, works in 22.17.1
items.body:
my CI fails with
```
 Exception during run: Error: Unexpected module status 0. Cannot require() ES Module /opt/atlassian/pipelines/agent/build/node_modules/node-pg-migrate/dist/bundle/index.js because it is not yet fully loaded. This may be caused by a race condition if the module is simultaneously dynamically import()-ed via Promise.all(). Try await-ing the import() sequentially in a loop instead. (from /opt/atlassian/pipelines/agent/build/test/integration/belote.spec.ts)
This is caused by either a bug in Node.js or incorrect usage of Node.js internals.
Please open an issue with this stack trace at https://github.com/nodejs/node/issues
    at Function.fail (node:internal/assert:17:9)
